Comenzó este negocio gracias a unos C$ 500 córdobas que tenia ahorrados, pero sus ventas las realiza al aire libre y necesita darle mantenimiento a la infraestructura de su local para mantener frescos y limpios sus productos (frutas, vegetales y legumbres).

Es madre soltera, pero ella y sus tres hijos son su familia, tiene a sus tres hijos en el colegio, pues su prioridad es alimentar a los niños y asegurarles una buena educación. Ha trabajado con 5 créditos qye le han ayudado a mejorar su nivel de vida, le ha ayudado a realizar las compras de contado, y de esta manera obtiene mejores ganancias.

Su proyecto actual es generar mas ganancia en el negocio para invertir en infraestructura.

loans.use: Purchase fruits and vegetables from wholesalers to stock her business.

loans.name: Relinda

texts.es:
Reliada is a woman who on a daily basis seeks for the bettering of her children. She works with great effort for them and wants to continue to do so to build a prominent and promising future. Ever since she was a little girl, she has been dedicated to farming activities. She was raised this way and has been a stable source of income until this day. She must start very early in the day with the chores that this activity demands as well as tend her small children. Her youngest is only nine months old and must take him with her in all the chores. Now that it is sowing season she works hardly to sow and tend the fields. She and her husband will continue to work in spite of the fact that they did not obtain substantial profits last season. Luckily for them, the frost did not damage a great portion of their harvest. They hope that this time the gathering of their products will be fructuous. To continue to work and to obtain a very good quantity and quality of potatoes, wheat, corn, and peas, Relinda asks for this loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers. Let’s show solidarity to this self-less mother that looks for what is best for her children.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Yáñez, Kiva volunteer.

Reliada, es una mujer que día a día busca la superación de sus hijos, trabaja denodadamente por ellos y quiere seguir trabajando para forjarles un futuro prominente y prometedor.Desde que era muy niña se ha dedicado a las actividades del campo, así creció y es para ella una fuente de ingresos económicos muy estable hasta el día de hoy.Desde muy temprano tiene que dedicarse a las labores que le demanda esta actividad y a la vez atender las solicitudes de sus pequeños ya que el menor de sus hijos tiene apenas nueve meses y en compañía de él tiene que realizar cada una de sus actividades; ahora que están en época de siembra trabaja con mayor esfuerzo para sembrar y posteriormente cuidar esos campos. Ella y su esposo seguirán trabajando a pesar de no haber tenido ganancias substanciales la temporada pasada y para suerte de ellos la implacable fuerza del frío no perjudicó en gran proporción sus cosechas y esperan que para esta ocasión el acopio de sus productos sea fructífero. Para seguir trabajando y para obtener una muy buena cantidad y calidad de papa, trigo, maíz y arvejas; Relinda solicita un préstamo para comprar semillas y abonos.Solidaricémonos con una madre abnegada que busca lo mejor para sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizers to better the quantity and quality of her products.

loans.name: Domingo

texts.es:
Domingo is 33 years old, lives with 29 year old Rosa María, and they have two young children.

Domingo is owner of a business that sells nutritionally balanced feed for animals like bird forage, horse, pig, bovine, etc. He has been doing this business for 4 years and it is going very well, and it generates good income for Domingo.

During this time of year, the sale of bird forage increases considerably as the raising of turkeys, chickens, ducks, etc. are growing for the end of year festivities.

Domingo is asking for a loan in order to purchase feed at wholesale prices.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

El Sr. Domingo de 33 años, vive en pareja con Rosa María de 29 años y tienen 2 hijos menores.

Domingo es propietario de un negocio de ventas de alimentos balanceados para animales tales como forrajes para aves, equinos, porcinos, vacunos, etc. Hace 4 años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien, ya que le genera buenas ganancias.

En esta época del año, las ventas de forrajes para aves aumentan considerablemente, ya que la cría de pollos, pavos, patos, etc. aumenta para las fiestas de fin de año.

Domingo solicita el crédito para la compra al por mayor de balanceados.

loans.use: Purchase nutritionally balanced animal feed at wholesale prices

loans.name: Nora Maria

texts.es:
Nora has been selling shoes for men, women and children for the past six years. She purchases her products wholesale and then sells them at retail. She started the business from savings from her previous job selling meat and yucca, and was able to establish a post in the local market. She recalls that it was very difficult for her when she started because she had to walk the streets to sell her shoes. Now she has moved up thanks to her earnings and investments made from previous loans.

Despite having a fixed space in the market, Nora lacks an actual sales post and at the moment sells her product outdoors. She wants to build a small stand to protect her products from the elements. Nora is a single mother and has three school-aged children. She has received 20 loans and is a woman who knows how to make the money work to help her improve her quality of life, increase her sales and purchase diverse and high-quality products.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Doña Nora lleva 6 años en este negocio, se dedica a vender calzados para damas, caballeros y niños, realiza las compras al por mayor y vende al detalle. Gracias a sus ahorros de las ganancias que tenia en su negocio anterior (venta de carne y yuca) ha logrado establecerse en el Mercado La Terminal-Leon. Recuerda que el inicio fué muy dificil, porque le tocaba caminar por todas las calles vendiendo zapatos, ahora esto ha sido superado gracias a las ganancias y a las inversiones que ha puesto en su negocio con los créditos obtenidos.

Pero a pesar de haberse establecido en el Mercado, le falta construir su módulo, por el momento vende al aire libre y du proyecto es hacer una pequeña construccion para proteger sus productos de la lluva y el sol. Es madre soltera y tiene 3 niños en edad escolar. Ha sido beneficiada con 20 créditos y es una señora que sabe administrar bien el dinero, sacando provecho de este y mejorar sus condiciones de vida, ha incrementado sus ventas y comprar productos de mejor calidad y variedad.

loans.use: Purchase footwear to sell.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es:
Rosa I. is a 34 year old woman. She is married to Jorge Espinoza who is 36 years old and works as a sales supervisor in a known company in the city. They have 2 children age 11 and 9, and they live in their own house.

Rosa owns a convenience store since 2001, she has her own commercial space and a truck with which she delivers her merchandise and provides freight services.

They started their own business from scratch, and thanks to their entrepreneurial spirit, they now own a flourishing small business. They have been clients of Fundacion Paraguaya for the past three years, who has helped them in the implementation of their projects.

With this new loan they will buy devices that they need to fit out a callshop next to their convenience store.

Translated from Spanish by Samantha, Kiva volunteer

Rosa I., tiene 34 años, esta casada con Jorge Espinoza de 36 años el trabaja como supervisor de ventas en una reconocida empresa de la ciudad. La pareja tiene 2 hijos, de 11 y de 9 años respectivamente. Ellos viven todos juntos en una casa propia.

Rosa posee una despensa desde el 2.001, posee local propio y un camión de cargas con el que realiza reparto de mercaderías y hace fletes a terceros.

El negocio lo empezaron de cero, gracias al espíritu emprendedor de la pareja, actualmente son dueños de una mini empresa floreciente. Son clientes de la Fundación Paraguaya hace 3 años y les hemos acompañado en la consecución de sus proyectos.

Con este nuevo préstamo comprarán algunos aparatos que les faltan para habilitar una cabina telefónica al lado de su despensa.

loans.use: To buy devices for callshop

loans.name: Josefa De Jesus

texts.es:
Josefa has had this business for 5 years. She invested her savings to open this business along with the inheritance that her mother left her. Before having her own business, she worked for a woman selling on a stretch of the Terminal-León market.

Little by little she has managed to provide maintenance for the infrastructure of her location. She constructed it with wood and concrete, but she still needs to finish building it. She is a single mother with 4 kids under her care. The four kids are studying in elementary school, and this fills her with happiness because she knows that thanks to her business, they will be able to get ahead.

She has had approximately 20 credits with CEPRODEL, and she is very thankful for the confidence they have in her to receive these loans, since they let her make favorable purchases and sell them at a good price.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Doña Josefa tiene 5 años de trabajar con este negocio, invirtió sus ahorros para abrir este negocio mas la herencia que le dejó su mamá. Antes de tener negocio propio era empleada por una señora para vender en un tramo del mercado la Terminal-León.

Poco a poco ha dado mantenimiento a la infraestructura de su módulo, de no tener nada ha logrado construirlo con Madera y concreto pero le falta terminar de construirlo. Ella es madre soltera con 4 hijos a su cargo, los cuatro niños estan estudiando la primaria y esto la llena de alegria porque sabe que gracias a su negocio...ellos han logrado salir adelante.

Manejó aproximadamente 20 créditos con CEPRODEL y se encuentra muy agradecida por la confianza que le han brindado para recibir estos préstamos, ya que con ellos logra hacer compras mas favorables y venderlas a un buen precio.

loans.use: Fruit and vegetable sales

loans.name: Alvaro Jose

texts.es:
Alvaro is an enterprising man. He has been selling fruits, legumes and vegetables at the local market in Leon, Nicaragua, for the past four years. He purchases his products from wholesalers (farmers who come to the city) and then sells them to customers at the market.

He started the business with the severance pay from his previous job. He currently has a fixed post at the market but is still in the outdoors, displaying his products in baskets and protecting them from the elements.

Alvaro is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. Previous loans have allowed him to improve and stock his business, helping him to benefit economically. He hopes to continue his good credit history and keep growing his business and moving his family ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Don Alvaro es un señor emprendedor, lleva 4 años trabajando en la venta de frutas, verduras y legumbres para las personas que llegan al mercado La Terminal, en León. Le compra los tomates, las chiltomas, las cebollas, papas y otros a los mayoristas (pequeños finqueros que llegan a la ciudad a vender su producción). Luego esto lo vende a los clientes que visitan el mercado

El, para tener su negocio invirtió la liquidacion que le dieron en su trabajo anterior. Sus ventas las realiza actualmente en un puesto fijo, pero aun al aire libre, exponiendo sus productos en los canastos y le da toda la luz del sol y la lluvia.

Don Alvaro es un señor casado, tiene a sus esposa y tres hijos que mantener de los cuales todos ellos estan estudiando, uno de ellos en la primaria y dos en secundaria.Los créditos que ha tenido le permiten mejorar y surtir el negocio, ha mejorado economicamente y desea mantener su buen historial crediticio para seguir creciendo y salir adelante con su esposa e hijos.

loans.use: Purchase fresh products (fruits, legumes and vegetables) to sell.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
Julia is a native of the Parco zone in Jauja, since childhood she’s been tied to agricultural activities and now that her parents are older this allows her the possibility to watch over them and satisfy each one of their needs. For personal reasons she has decided not to marry and instead treasure a fruitful life of all the different business ideas she hopes to accomplish. She recently undertook to raising and selling of small farm animals such as guinea pigs and chickens as a formal business. Julia is very charismatic and warm, her personality making her beloved by everyone around her. She believes her place in this world is to help those that need her, always do good, and help your neighbors; all this has made her a leader in her zone. Julia has become the only support of her aging parents and she wishes to give them a successful farm in retribution for all they did for her as a child. Her ambition to keep on succeeding have led her to slowly grow every one of her little businesses in order to commercialize her products and small farm animals at the market in her zone. She asks for this loan to use as investment capital to improve the farm conditions for her animals and buy more fertilizer and seeds for her fields. Let us help a noble heart full of hope to realize her goals.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva Volunteer.

Julia es natural de la zona de Parco en Jauja, desde muy pequeña estuvo ligada a las actividades agrícolas y ahora que sus padres están muy ancianos esta actividad le otorga la posibilidad de velar por ellos y satisfacer cada una de sus necesidades. Por razones personales ella ha decidido no casarse y atesorar una vida llena de experiencias fructíferas en los diferentes negocios que tiene en mente realizar.Hace poco ha emprendido el negocio de crianza y venta de animales menores tales como el cuy y los pollos de manera más formal. Julia es una persona muy carismática y acogedora, su manera de ser hace que sea bien querida por todos los que la rodean y siempre dice que su función aquí es poder ayudar a quienes la necesitan y siempre hace el bien y contribuye con sus vecinos; es por ello que es toda un líder por su zona.Julia ahora se ha convertido en el único sostén de sus padres ya ancianos y quiere darles una decorosa estancia en este mundo en retribución a lo que ellos dieron cuando ella era niña. Los deseos enormes de seguir progresando la han llevado a incrementar cada uno de sus pequeños negocios para comercializar sus productos y animalitos en la feria de su zona.Solicita un préstamo para utilizarlos como capital de inversión y mejorar la granja de sus animalitos adicionalmente comprar mayor cantidad de abonos y semillas para los campos que cultiva.Apoyemos a un noble corazón lleno de esperanza a concretar sus nobles ideales.

loans.use: To repair the chicken coop and buy larger quanities and varieties of seeds and fertilizer for a successful harvest.

loans.name: Flor De Maria

texts.es:
Doña Flor de María is a woman who started her clothing sales business out of small baskets. She would walk through the streets of the city of León with the baskets on her head to display her products. She did this for two years, exposed to the sun and the bad weather during some seasons. Thanks to the credits she received, she managed to obtain a location in La Terminal market in León.

While she has a location, she still needs to invest in building a shelter for it, and this is her goal for this next year, to have money to invest in and improve the infrastructure. She buys her clothes on a wholesale basis and then sells them as retail. She is married with two kids who are of school age. Her credits have helped her better her economic situation because she can buy better products and increase her sales, and logically, her profits.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Doña Flor de maria es una señora que comenzó poniendo el negocio de venta de ropa en unas canastas pequeñas, caminaba por las calles de la ciudad de León con los canastos en su cabeza para exponer sus productos, llevó dos años así, exponiendose al sol y al mal clima de algunas temporadas. Gracias a los créditos, ella se logró establecer en el mercado La Terminal en León.

Pero buen, ya logro establecerse pero aun le falta invertir para construir su módulo y ese es su propósito para el proximo año....tener ya el dinero para invertir y mejorar la infraestructura. Como ella realiza las compras al por mayor y los vende al detalle. Es una señora Casada con dos hijos en edad escolar. Los créditos le han ayudado a mejorar su situacion económica, comprando mejores productos y de esta manera incrementar las ventas y logicamente sus ganancias.

loans.use: Purchase of clothes to sell to her clients.

loans.name: Lupe

texts.es:
For the past 4 years, Lupe has belonged to the "Las Almendras" communal bank. She lives in the Calleria district, in the department of Ucayali. She is 57 and the mother of 3 children. She was widowed 20 years ago, and for that reason decided to put up a mechanic workshop in her house, in partnership with her son.

In addition to the workshop, she also sells beauty products. She is both mother and father for her family.

With a loan from Manuela Ramos which she will pay back in 5 months, she plans to expand the workshop as well as buy a compressor, a filing machine, and an awning.

Lupe is happy to have 3 wonderful children who support her in her business. She thanks God she has the strength to help her family get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Lupe pertenece, desde hace 4 años, al Banco Comunal Las Almendras, ella vive en el Jr. Francisco Pizarro 147 del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 57 años y es madre de 3 hijos, es viuda desde hace 20 años, por esa razón decidió poner, en sociedad con su hijo, un taller de mecánica en su casa.

En la actualidad cuenta con el taller de mecánica; pero también se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza. Ella es padre y madre para su hogar.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos el cual será pagado en 5 meses, ampliará el local y también comprará una compresora , un afilador y una carpa.

Lupe está muy contenta de tener a sus 3 hijos buenos, que la apoyan en el negocio y también agradece a Dios el tener mucha fuerza para sacar a su familia adelante.

loans.use: Purchase of machinery.  Purchase of awning.

loans.name: Nora

texts.es:
NoR. belongs to the "Las Almendras" communal bank, in the district of Calleria, department of Ucayali. She is 55 years old and the mother of 7 children. Her husband is retired and has a small sawmill.

She currently has a stand in the La Hoyada market where she sells cured meats, sausage, and maize. Two of her children help out, and they are the reason she is motivated to work hard and sacrifice to get ahead.

With a loan from Manuel Ramos which will be paid back in 5 months, she will buy 2 pigs and 2 sacks of maize.

NoR. is very happy that she has 7 healthy children and that she has been successful in having them complete their studies. The older ones now have families but she still needs to educate the younger ones. And she does not mind investing in her family´s progress.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señoR. NoR. pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Almendras, ella vive el Jr. Espinar 293 D. Distrito de Calleria D. Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 55 años y es madre de 7 hijos, su esposo es Jubilado y cuenta con un pequeño aserradero.

En la actualidad cuenta con un puesto en el mercado La Hoyada, en donde vende cecina (carne), chorizo, maiz, y recibe el apoyo de 2 de sus hijos, quienes son su compañía y el motivo por la cual ella se sacrifica paR. sacarlos adelante.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará 2 chanchos y dos sacos de maíz

NoR. está muy contenta de tener a sus 7 hijos sanos y haber logrado que terminen sus estudios. Los mayores ya tienen familia pero aun falta educar a los más pequeños. Y no se arrepiente de invertir en el progreso de su familia.

loans.use: Purchase of pigs.  Purchase of maize (grain).

loans.name: Rubí

texts.es:
Doña Rubí belongs to “Banco Comunal Las Tigresas”, she lives in Jr. Adolfo Morey 466, District of Calleria, Department of Ucayali. She is 52 years old and mother of 3 children, her husband is a watchman at a state institution and she also breeds small animals on her property.

Presently she also sells, buys, and barters used garments in the town of Atalaya where she travels monthly with her son who supports her in this arduous activity.

The loan requested, $525, will be invested in the purchase of used garments and she plans to repay the funds in 6 months. Doña Rubí is very pleased to have 3 healthy children, 2 of them having their own family and she feels very satisfied as they have been successful with their studies. She is very happy because she is succeeding in caring for her family properly and at the same time she feels useful and productive.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer

La señora Rubí pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Tigresas, vive en el Jr. Adolfo Morey 466 del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 52 años y es madre de 3 hijos, su esposo es vigilante en una institución estatal y se dedica a la crianza de animales menores en su misma casa.

En la actualidad se dedica a la compra y venta de ropa usada, con la cual realiza trueques (intercambio) en la ciudad de Atalaya, viaja mensualmente con su hijo, el cual la apoya en este trabajo sacrificado.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,500 (US$ 503.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 6 meses, comprará mas ropa usada. Rubí está muy contenta de tener a sus 3 hijos sanos, y que 2 de ellos ya tengan familia, además está satisfecha de haber logrado que terminen sus estudios. Se siente muy feliz porque está logrando sacar adelante a su familia y la vez se siente útil y productiva.

loans.use: Purchase of used garments to increase sales.

loans.name: Noelia

texts.es:
Noelia is a woman with dreams of getting ahead. She saved for a long time to come up with 5,000 cordobas to be able to start her business of selling various products 11 years ago. At first, she rented the location of her business, but thanks to her efforts, she has managed to buy it. It is in good condition, made of concrete with an artificial floor. It's located in the central market in the city of Chinandega. Before opening her own business, she worked as a street vendor.

The work that this head of family has done has been gratifying because it has let her take good care of her son. Now she feels happy and fortunate because in addition to the love of her son, she has the love of her grandson. Her work with CEPRODEL started around 3 years ago, and she has had 15 credits.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

NOELIA ES UNA MUJER CON DESEOS DE SUPERACIÓN. DURANTE MUCHO TIEMPO AHORRO PARA REUNIR LA CANTIDAD DE CS$5,000.00 PARA PODER COMENZAR SU NEGOCIO DE PRODUCTOS VARIOS HACE11 AÑOS.

AL INICIO ALQUILABA EL LOCAL, PERO GRACIAS A SUS ESFUERZOS LO LOGRO COMPRAR. LAS CONDICIONES SON BUENAS, PUES EL LOCAL ES DE CONCRETO CON PISO ARTIFICIAL Y ESTA UBICADO EN EL MERCADO CENTRAL DE LA CIUDAD DE CHINANDEGA. ANTES DE PONER SU PROPIO NEGOCIO ERA VENDEDORA AMBULANTE.

EL TRABAJO QUE HA DESEMPEÑADO ESTA JEFA DE FAMILIA LE HA SIDO GRATIFICANTE PUES HA SACADO A SU HIJO ADELANTE Y AHORA SE SIENTE FELIZ Y DICHOSA YA QUE ADEMAS DEL AMOR DE SU HIJO TIENE EL AMOR DE SU NIETO.

SU TRABAJO CON CEPRODEL INICIA HACE ALREDEDOR DE 3 AÑOS CON UN PROMEDIO DE 15 CRÉDITOS.

loans.use: Purchase of general merchandise

loans.name: Eustaquia

texts.es:
Eustaquia is a hard working woman. Early each day she gets ready to go to the agricultural fields she works with her husband, carrying her tools for working the land with the help of her little friend, Silverio. They raise potatoes, root vegetables, corn and broadbeans; additionally, they herd a few small animals. The work is difficult and requires much dedication and strength.

Eustaquia is the mother of four children. The oldest daughter is married and the younger children study; for this reason her goal is to keep working. Now that it is planting season, the days are more exhausting. Her family hopes that this harvest is successful, because a year ago extreme cold considerably damaged their harvest and caused numerous losses, making it impossible for them to meet all their needs. However, her courage and perseverance pushed her to continue with her activities, and their means of support during this time was the sale of their animals.

For Estaquia, the land is a way of life and each day she thanks God for what they receive from it. She wants to keep working and that is why she is asking for a loan to invest in the purchase of fertilizers for their land. Please support this woman who lives simply but has a tremendous will to succeed.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

Eustaquia, es una mujer muy trabajadora; todos los días desde muy temprano se alista para dirigirse a sus campos de cultivo junto a su esposo, llevando con ayuda de su amiguito Silverio sus herramientas para labrar la tierra; ellos cultivan papa, olluco, maíz y habas adicionalmente pastan algunos animalitos. Este trabajo es arduo debido a que requiere de mucha dedicación y fortaleza.

Eustaquia es madre de cuatro hijos, la mayor ya está casada y los menores aún estudian, por esta razón se ha planteado la meta de seguir trabajando y ahora que es época de siembra los días son más agotadores y su familia espera que esta cosecha sea muy provechosa porque hace un año la implacable fuerza del frío perjudicó considerablemente su cosecha y les ocasionó cuantiosas perdidas imposibilitando la satisfacción plena de sus necesidades; sin embargo su esfuerzo y perseverancia la impulsaron a continuar con sus actividades y su sostén durante las épocas de pérdida agrícola fue la venta de ganado.

Para ella el campo es su forma de vida y agradece a Dios por la provisión diaria que recibe. Desea seguir trabajando y es por ello que ahora solicita un préstamo para invertirlos en la compra de abono para sus tierras.Apoyemos a una mujer de humilde de corazón y condición con enormes fuerzas para triunfar.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers to insure success for the next harvest.

loans.name: Magda

texts.es:
Doña Magda has prepared every type of Nicaraguan food and drink for four years. Before, she had a business just in her house, but she was advised to move it to La Terminal market in León. She needs to repair some equipment, the stove, and the infrastructure of her location, and also needs to buy the products that she needs to make different dishes and sell them to the workers in the market, students, and clients in general that come to her location to eat delicious food.

She is very thankful for the four credits she has received because she has been able to increase her capital. She has improved her quality of life, and her two children don't need anything. They always have their three daily meals secured. One of the most important things for Magda is that she feels proud of being a single mother, and her children are studying so they can be good people in this life.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Doña Magda prepara todo tipo de comida nicaragüense y refrescos desde hace 4 años, ella antes tenia el negocio solo en su casa pero le aconsejaron establecerse en el mercado La Terminal de León.

Ella necesita hacer una reparación del equipo, la cocina y de la infraestructura de su local, tambien comprar los productos que necesita para hacer los diferente platillos y venderlos a los trabajadores del mercado, estudiantes y clientela en general que llegan siempre a su módulo para comprar esa deliciosa comida.

Esta muy agradecida ya que con los créditos que ha tenido (4 créditos) ha logrado aumentar su capital de trabajo, ha mejorado su nivel de vida y a sus dos hijos no les falta nada, siempre tienen asegurado sus tres tiempos de comida, y una de las cosas mas importantes es que ella se siente orgullosa de ser madre soltera y tener a sus hijos estudiando para que sean personas de bien en esta vida.

loans.use: Purchase of products to cook and sell food

loans.name: Maritza Angelica

texts.es:
Maritza Angélica is 40-years-old, and she lives in the district of La Esperanza in the province of Trujillo in La Libertad. She only studied through elementary school. She has 5 children, but only one still depends on her. She started her business with the help of her husband. She has a small shop where she makes children's shoes. She used to sell them as a street vendor by traveling the streets in the La Hermelinda and El Mayorista markets.

Now her shop has grown and she makes, in addition to children's shoes, shoes and sandals for women. She employs two young people. The growth has also allowed her to rent a stand in an important shopping center on a centrally-located avenue in the city of Trujillo, which a worker attends so she can continue making her sales on the streets of the city.

Maritza is a member of the Grupo Mientras Tanto Manuel Seoane. She received her first loan of 300 nuevos soles (about $101), with which she bought leather to make shoes. With this loan from Manuela Ramos of 500 nuevos soles (about $168), to be repaid in 4 months, she will buy insoles to make sandals for the end of the year celebrations. Maritza dreams about having a large shoe factory with cutting-edge technology.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Maritza Angélica tiene 40 años de edad, vive en el distrito de La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo departamento de La Libertad.

Estudió solo primaria completa; tiene 5 hijos pero sólo uno depende de ella. La señora Maritza inició su negocio con la ayuda de su esposo. Tiene un pequeño taller artesanal de confección de zapatos para niños, ella solía vender de forma ambulante recorriendo las calles de los mercados “La Hermelinda” y “El Mayorista”.

Actualmente su taller ha crecido y ahora confecciona, a parte del calzado para niños, zapatos y sandalias para damas, dando empleo a dos jóvenes. El crecer le ha permitido también alquilar un stand en una galería importante de una avenida céntrica de la ciudad de Trujillo, donde atiende una trabajadora porque ella continúa realizando sus ventas por las calles de la ciudad.

La señora es socia del Grupo Mientras Tanto “Manuel Seoane”, obtuvo su primer préstamos de S/.300.00 (aproximadamente $101) con el cual compró cuero para la confección de calzado. Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.500.00 (aproximadamente $168), para ser cancelado en 4 meses, comprará plantas para fabricar sandalias de fiesta, las cuales venderá en estas fiestas de fin de año.La señora Maritza sueña con tener una fabrica de calzado grande y con tecnología de punta.

loans.use: Purchase of shoe insoles

loans.name: Marta

texts.es:
Doña Marta is 64 years old and she lives in the “caserío” Canchachugo, District of Usquil, Province of Otuzzco, Department of La Libertad. She studied until first grade, elementary school as her parents decided to school only her brothers because of lack of funding.

Since she was very young she helped her parents with the farming and breeding of livestock. When she was 17 years old she fell in love with a young neighbor and gave birth to two children but she never formalized the relationship as she did not want to leave her mother so her partner moved away and she alone brought up her children.

Due to the necessity to bring up her children she started selling bread rolls and cakes at the local market places. A previous loan of $100 from the Banco Comunal “Canchachugo” was invested in buying flour and cereals in order to sell her product in small quantities and other loans were used to increase the purchase of products and therefore also increase the sales.

Today she is selling cereals, flour, and meat from her community at the market of Santo Dominguito in the town of Trujillo The funds requested from Manuela Ramos, $525 will be invested in purchasing cereals, flour, and pea for wholesale. Doña Martha plans to repay the loan in 4 months. She is very pleased with her business as she has been able to school her children and save a little money as her goal is to buy a house in Trujillo to live there with her children.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Marta tiene 64 años de edad, vive en el caserío Canchachugo del Distrito de Usquil de la Provincia de Otuzzco en el Departamento de La Libertad. Estudió solo hasta primer grado de primaria debido a que sus padres, por falta de recursos, prefirieron darle educación a sus hermanos varones.

Desde muy pequeña ayudó a sus padres con las labores de la chacra y la crianza de ganado. A los 17 años se enamoró de un joven de la zona y tuvo dos hijos con él, nunca formalizó su relación porque no quiso dejar sola a su madre para ir con su pareja, es así que él se aleja y ella se queda sola a criar a sus niños.

Debido a la necesidad de criar a sus hijos, es que se inicia en el negocio vendiendo roscas y pasteles por los diferentes caseríos en los días de feria; posteriormente, con su primer crédito que obtuvo en el Banco Comunal “Canchachugo” de S/ 300 (aproximadamente $100), compró harina y cereales para vender sus productos en pequeñas cantidades y con los créditos posteriores ha ido incrementando la compra de productos y por lo tanto también la venta.

Actualmente trae de su caserío cereales, harina y carne para vender en el mercado Santo Dominguito de la ciudad de Trujillo.Con el reciente préstamos recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,500 (aproximadamente $502), el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará cereales, harina de trigo y arveja para vender al por mayor.La señora Marta está muy contenta con su negocio, con él ha podido educar a sus dos hijos y además tiene algunos ahorros porque su meta es comprarse una casa en Trujillo para venir a vivir con sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase cereal, flour, and pea to increase wholesale business.

loans.name: Domitila T.

texts.es:
Doña Domitila is 49 years old, she lives in “Centro Poblado Menor San Luís, District of Salpo, Province of Otuzco, Department of La Libertad. She belongs to “Banco Comunal Mujeres Trabajadoras” (Communal Bank for Working Women).

She studied until second grado, elementary school and has no children. She started selling used garments in small quantities and today she sells shoes in her community especially at the market of the District of Carabamba on Sundays. The shoes are manufactured by her husband. She also sells cereals part of which is from her own crop and part which she purchases from other communities.

A previous loan from Manuela Ramos, approximately $100, was invested in cereals and the funds requested, $775, will be invested in the purchase of material for the manufacture of shoes, such as leather, glue, needles and synthetic material. She plans to repay the loan in a period of 4 months.

Doña Domitila’s dream is to buy her own house at Trujillo and adopt a child as she did not have the opportunity of giving birth herself.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Domitila tiene 49 años de edad, vive en el Centro Poblado Menor San Luís, Distrito de Salpo provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad. Pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Trabajadoras".

Estudió solo hasta el segundo grado de primaria y no tienen hijos. Inició su negocio vendiendo ropa usada en pequeñas cantidades y actualmente se dedica a la venta de zapatos tanto en su comunidad como en el mercado del Distrito de Carabamba, esto lo hace los días domingos. Estos zapatos son confeccionados por su esposo; además vende también cereales que ella siembra y otros que compra en comunidades más alejadas.

Con el primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.300 (aproximadamente $100) el cual lo invirtió en la compra de cereales. Con el reciente préstamo de S/. 2,300.00 (aproximadamente $772) para cancelarlo en 4 meses, comprará materiales para la elaboración del calzado como: cuero, pegamentos, agujas y material sintético. La señora Domitila sueña con comprarse una casa en Trujillo y adoptar un niño porque no tuvo la oportunidad de tener uno propio.

loans.use: Purchase material for the manufacture and sale of shoes.

loans.name: Andrea

texts.en:
Andrea, 50, is a disciplined, assiduous and persistent single mother. Her husband died fifteen years ago and left her with nine children to support. She says that she had to struggle to make a living. Shortly after her husband’s death, she opened a very small grocery store and had to close it two years later. In 1997, she started over, and the business still exists in spite of everything.

Her grocery store offers various types of products, such as rice, beans, flour, milk, rum and sugar. She says she makes a weekly profit of $120.

The entrepreneur has applied for a loan (her second loan with this microcredit organization) to purchase more goods to supply her business. She will also remodel the store in order to improve the hygienic conditions of the space where she runs the business.

loans.use: To purchase goods to supply her grocery store and remodel the store

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Gloria is a mother who is proud of being hard-working because she sets the example for her children that it's necessary to fight in life to succeed. She has six children, of whom five are of school age. God has also blessed her with a grandson, in whom she tries to instill good principles from early on in life.

More than four years ago, Gloria decided to start her business because the work she did selling lottery tickets wasn't enough income to support her home. Her biggest dream is to see her children become professionals so they don't have to suffer in life. She started her business with 2,000 cordobas that her husband contributed.

She has worked with CEPRODEL for more than two years with a record of 10 credits. She feels satisfied because in this time, she has made her business prosper.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

GLORIA ES UNA MADRE DE FAMILIA ORGULLOSA DE SER TRABAJADORA PORQUE DA EJEMPLO A SUS HIJOS QUE EN LA VIDA HAY QUE LUCHAR PARA PODER SALIR ADELANTE. TIENE 6 HIJOS DE LOS CUALES 5 ESTAN EN EDAD ESCOLAR Y DIOS LA HA BENDECIDO CON UN NIETO AL CUAL TRATA DE INCULCARLE BUENOS PRINCIPIOS DESDE PEQUEÑO.

HACE MAS DE 4 AÑOS QUE GLORIA DECIDE COLOCAR SU NEGOCIO PORQUE A RAÍZ DE QUE EL TRABAJO DE VENDEDORA DE LOTERIA NO ERA SUFICIENTE INGRESO PARA EL SUSTENTO DE SU HOGAR. SU MAYOR ANHELO ES QUE SUS HIJOS SE PREPAREN Y SEAN PROFESIONALES PARA NO TENER QUE SUFRIR EN LA VIDA. ELLA EMPIEZA SU NEGOCIO CON UN CAPITAL DE CS$2,000.00 APORTADOS EN ESE ENTONCES POR SU ESPOSO

TRABAJA CON CEPRODEL DESDE HACE 2 AÑOS CON UN RÉCORD DE 10 CRÉDITOS, TIEMPO EN EL CUAL SE SIENTE SATISFECHA PORQUE HA HECHO QUE SU NEGOCIO PROSPERE.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Carmen Rosa

texts.es:
Señora Carmen Rosa is 32-years-old. She lives in Cruz de Pargo, a town in the district of Salpo in the province of Otuzco in La Libertad. She went to school until 6th grade. She has 4 children who depend on her. She started her business with the first credit she received from Manuela Ramos as a member of the Communal Bank "Mujeres Trabajadoras" (hard-working women). She received 300 nuevos soles from them (about $100) five years ago. She used to devote herself to housework and helping her husband on their small farm. With this money, she bought cuajada (a yogurt-like product) and took it to Trujillo to sell. This is how she started a grocery store little by little in her community. She still takes cuajada to Trujillo on Wednesdays and Saturdays. This loan from Manuela Ramos of 1,200 nuevos soles (about $403), to be repaid in 4 months, will be used to buy rice, sugar, noodles, canned goods, and other products to supply her grocery store. Her main goal is to see her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Carmen Rosa tiene 32 años, ella vive en Cruz de Pargo, Caserío del Distrito de Salpo, Provincia de Otuzco. Departamento La Libertad, estudió hasta el 6to de primaria, tiene 4 hijos que dependen de ella. La señora Carmen Rosa inició su negocio con el primer crédito que recibió de Manuela Ramos en su Banco Comunal "Mujeres Trabajadoras", el monto recibido fue de S/ 300.00 soles ($ 100.00), esto fue hace cinco años, ya que antes se dedicaba a los quehaceres de su casa y ayudar a su esposo en la chacra; con este dinero compró cuajada y lo llevó a vender a Trujillo y así poco a poco fue implementando una bodega en su comunidad, aún así continúa llevando cuajada a Trujillo los días miércoles y sábados. El reciente préstamo recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/.1,200.00 (aproximadamente $403), el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, será utilizado para comprar arroz, azúcar, fideos, conservas y otros productos para surtir su bodega. Su mayor es ver profesionales a sus hijos.

loans.use: Purchase of various products for a grocery store

loans.name: Irma Ermitana

texts.es:
Irma, 60, lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She never had a chance to go to school because her parents couldn't afford to send her. She has 1 son who depends on her for support.

Irma began her business selling cuajada (cheese) because she used to have an alcoholic husband who couldn't support her and only gave her problems. She decided to start selling cuajada in the nearby city of Trujillo. She got started with a S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$101) from the Manuela Ramos Movement's Luchando por el Progreso ("Fighting for Progress") community bank. With subsequent loans, she bought live animals that she raises and sells; she also grows and sells farm crops: potatoes, beans, corn. With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.1,300 (about US$436), to be repaid in 4 months, she will buy cuajada and animal feed.

Irma dreams of having her own house in Trujillo and a stand in some market there where she can sell products that she brings from her home village.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Irma tiene 60 años, ella vive en el Caserío Cruz de Pargo, del Distrito de Salpo, Provincia de Otuzco, Departamento de La Libertad, no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar, por falta de apoyo de sus padres. Tiene 1 solo hijo que depende de ella.

La señora Irma se inició en el negocio de venta de cuajada (quesillo) porque tenía un esposo alcohólico que solo le daba problemas y no le ayudaba económicamente, es así que decidió dedicarse a trabajar vendiendo cuajada en la ciudad de Trujillo. En este negocio invirtió su primer préstamo de S/ 300.00 (aproximadamente $101) que recibió en su Banco Comunal “Luchando por el Progreso” del Movimiento Manuela Ramos. Posteriormente con los otros préstamos que recibió compró animales los cuales cría y vende, además se dedica también a la agricultura y vende los productos de la cosecha: papa, habas, maíz. El reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,300.00 (aproximadamente $436) el cual será pagarlo en 4 meses, lo utilizará para comprar cuajada y alimento para sus animales.

La señora Irma sueña con tener su casa propia en Trujillo y además comprar un puesto en algún mercado de esta ciudad para que allí pueda ofertar los productos que trae de su comunidad.

loans.use: Buy cuajada (cheese) and animal feed.

loans.name: Adria Iris

texts.es:
Adria Iris, 45 years old, with little education and 4 children who depend on her, is a very optimistic and dynamic lady. She lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. Her parents taught her to make bread as a very small girl and, before she married, she used to make a living selling bread. Then she realized that her neighbors needed other things that they couldn't get so she decided to open a small general store with an initial loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$101), borrowed through the Mujeres Trabajadores ("Working Women") community bank. Adria now also sells food; that's to say, she provides meals to teachers that work in the area.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.900 (900 Peruvian soles or about US$302), to be repaid in 4 months, Adria will buy rice, sugar, cooking oil, milk, pasta, etc. to stock her store. The rest of the loan will be used to buy basic supplies for the prepared meals that she sells.

Adria dreams of leaving something for her still-young children, a house for each one, perhaps, and also of seeing them start professional careers, something that will be up to one of them to do to be able to help the rest.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Adria Iris a sus 45 años de edad, con grado de instrucción 3º grado de primaria y con 4 hijos que dependen de ella, es una señora muy optimista y dinámica, vive en el barrio Milán en el Distrito de Salpo, provincia de Otuzco. Departamento de La Libertad. Desde muy pequeña aprendió de sus padres el negocio de la preparación de pan, posteriormente, antes que se case se dedicó a la venta del mismo. Luego se dio cuenta que sus vecinos tenían otras necesidades no satisfechas, es así que, gracias al primer préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00 (aproximadamente $101) que obtuvo en su Banco Comunal “Mujeres Trabajadoras”, abrió una pequeña bodega. Actualmente la señora Adria también vende comida, es decir, da pensión a todos los profesores que trabajan en la zona.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/ 900.00 soles (aproximadamente $302), el cual será cancelado en 4 meses, comprará arroz, azúcar, aceite, leche, fideos, etc., con esto podrá surtir su bodega. Otra parte será utilizada en la copra de insumos para la preparación de los alimentos que vende a sus pensionistas.

Ella sueña con dejarles algo a sus niños que están aun pequeños, quizás una casa a cada uno y también sueña con verlos profesionales aunque sea a uno de ellos para que pueda ayudar al resto.

loans.use: Buy general merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Petrona

texts.en:
Petrona is a 52-year-old single mother of five children, three girls and two boys. Her boys work in the town as farmers. Her daughters are housekeepers.

For more than eight years, Petrona has been running a small general store. She sells different kinds of foodstuffs, such as bread, butter, seasoning and spices, vegetables and fruits. With her small business, she manages to make a living and take care of her children.

Petrona hopes she can enlarge the store and offer more products to her clientele. She is requesting a loan to buy more goods to sell. Additional income will help the entrepreneur keep on improving her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for her grocery store

loans.name: Juana Magdalena

texts.es:
Juana, 60, didn't go to school because her parents didn't consider it important. She now has 2 children who count on her. She lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad and belongs to the Mujeres Trabajadoras ("Working Women") community bank. Her parents taught her how to make clay pots and she used to make a living selling them. Later, after getting an initial loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$101), she began selling shoes that she brought from Trujillo to buyers in her neighborhood and nearby markets. She's been making a living from the business for five years.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.2,000 (about US$671), to be repaid in 4 months, she will buy footwear that is especially in demand during December because of the graduation ceremonies celebrated during the month.

Juana dreams of seeing her grandchildren take up professional careers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Juana tiene 60 años, no estudió porque sus padres no lo consideraron importante. Tiene 2 hijos que dependen de ella, vive en barrio Milán Distrito de Salpo, Provincia de Otuzco, Departamento de La Libertad. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Trabajadoras”. Aprendió de sus padres a elaborar ollas de barro y en un primer momento se dedicó a esta actividad pero posteriormente obtuvo su primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/.300.00 (aproximadamente $101) en el Banco Comunal “Mujeres Trabajadoras” y empezó a llevar zapatos de Trujillo para venderlos en su comunidad y en las ferias de comunidades cercanas. Hace cinco años que se dedica a este negocio.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 2,000.00 (aproximadamente $671) para cancelarlo en 4 meses, compró calzado para fiesta, debido a que en el mes de diciembre se celebran las fiestas de promoción y este tipo de calzado tiene mucha salida.

La señora Juana sueña con ver a sus nietos profesionales.

loans.use: Buy footwear for resale.

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en:
Paulina sells men’s and women’s clothing. She started her business eight years ago. Paulina is 43 years old and has six children, four boys and two girls. Four of them are grown and are working in Santo Domingo. The two youngest attend school.

Paulina says she’s very proud to have worked hard in order to provide good education for her children. But her major satisfaction is to run her business and not depend on others to have food to eat. She hopes her business can get better and better.

With her loan, she will buy clothing in bulk and shoes to introduce into the business. That way she hopes she will increase her sales volume and attract new clients.

loans.use: To purchase clothing in bulk and shoes for her business

loans.name: María Elsa

texts.es:
Maria Elsa, 36, lives in the Peruvian "departamento" of La Libertad. She only went to school for two years. She now has four children, all of whom depend on her.

She earns a living selling flan and gelatin-based deserts that she makes herself. Maria Elsa's sister-in-law helped her get started and she's been working at the business for 12 years now. She felt it was necessary to help her husband with household costs because four children are expensive and the business was her way of helping. She goes every day to the La Hermelinda market in the city of Trujillo and sells her products there during the mornings. On weekends, when they're not in school, her children help her by selling in other parts of the market.

Maria Elsa found out about Manuela Ramos from her mother who is a member of a community bank in the Peruvian "provincia" of Julcan. She joined an affiliated group, Dios Guia Nuestros Pasos ("God Guides Our Steps") and, with her first loan of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$100), bought basic supplies for making flan and gelatin deserts: disposable cups, spoons, bags and sugar. With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.700 (about US$234), to be repaid in 4 months, she will buy the basic things she needs for the business, including bulk supplies of sugar to ensure that she only pays wholesale prices for it.

Maria Elsa is very motivated and wants to continue to work hard for her dream of one day owning her own house.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora María Elsa tiene 36 años de edad, vive en el distrito de Florencia de Mora, provincia de Trujillo departamento de La Libertad. Estudió solo hasta segundo de secundaria; tiene 4 hijo menores de edad que dependen de ella.

Se dedica a la venta de gelatina y flan los cuales son preparados por ella misma; la señora María Elsa ya tiene 12 años trabajando en este negocio y fue gracias a su cuñada que se inició en él. Sentía la necesidad de apoyar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar ya que tener cuatro hijos demanda gastos y es así como empieza con el negocio; sale todos los días al mercado La Hermelinda de la ciudad de Trujillo y camina vendiendo toda la mañana; los fines de semana cuando los niños no van al colegio le ayudan con la venta por otras zonas del mismo mercado.

La señora María Elsa se enteró de Manuela Ramos por medio de su mamá quien es socia de un Banco Comunal del distrito de Carabamba provincia de Julcán. Formó su Grupo Mientras Tanto “Dios Guía Nuestros Pasos” Obtuvo su primer crédito de S/.300.00 (aproximadamente $100) con los que compró algunos insumos para la preparación de gelatina y flan; vasos descartables, cucharas, bolsas y azúcar. El reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/.700.00 (aproximadamente $234) el cual será pagado en 4 meses, le sirvió para invertir en los insumos que se necesita para la preparación de gelatina y flan y también compró azúcar al por mayor antes que suba el precio.

La señora María Elsa está muy motivada y quiere continuar trabajando muy duro porque su mayor sueño es comprarse su casa.

loans.use: Buy supplies for making deserts.

loans.name: Fior Daliza

texts.en:
Fior Daliza has been running a small cafeteria for more than three years. She is 31 years old and has two children, a boy and a girl. They attend primary school. Her husband is a plumber.

Fior Daliza’s cafeteria is well known by people of the town. Early in the morning, she starts to operate the business. She prepares sandwiches, spaghetti, boiled and fried eggs, boiled manioc, natural fruit juice and milk. She hopes that in the future the cafeteria can be enlarged and that her clientele can grow. Fior Daliza also hopes she will have sufficient funds to remodel the location where she runs the business.

With her loan, she will buy more ingredients in order to prepare more dishes and have the opportunity to sell more and augment profits from business. That way, Fior Daliza will be able to save money to keep on improving her children's education.

loans.use: To buy ingredients to prepare food for her small cafeteria

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Olga belongs to the Las Almendras ("The Almonds") community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of Ucayali. She is 62 years old and the mother of 4 children. Due to an illness, her husband can no longer work, though he can help her with household chores. To earn a living, Olga decided to open a small general store with an initial loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$100). She now counts on the store which she tends along with her children. They get up very early and tend the store after breakfast. The older children were already independent but they never forget the great efforts and sacrifices that their mother makes for them.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.1,000 (about US$336), to be repaid in 5 months, Olga will expand the store and buy bulk supplies of milk, rice, sugar, soft drinks and cooking oil.

Olga is very happy to have 4 healthy children who have completed school and to be with her husband despite the difficulties his poor health bring.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Olga pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Almendras, D. Jr. CahuiD. 403 D. Distrito D. Calleria D. Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 62 años y es madre D. 4 hijos, debido a una enfernedad su esposo no pueD. salir a trabajar, sin embargo si le ayuda en las tareas D. la casa. Por esta razón, Olga, con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/ 300 soles deciD. poner un pequeña bodega. En la actualidad cuenta con dicha bodega, la misma que atienD. junto con sus hijos, se levantanmuy temprano y después D. hacer el desayuno atienD. la bodega, sus hijos mayores ya se independizaron económicamente pero nunca olvidan el gran esfuerzo y sacrificio que hace su madre.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 1,000 (US$ 336.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 5 meses, ampliará el local D. negocio y comprará 2 caja D. leche, 2 saco D. arroz, 2 saco D. azúcar, 5 cajas D. gaseosa y 3 bidones D. aceite.

Olga está muy contenta D. tener a sus 4 hijos sanos y haber logrado que terminen sus estudios, además D. estar junto a su esposo pese a las dificultades D. salud que tiene.

loans.use: Buy general merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.es:
Consuelo belongs to the Las Almendras ("The Almonds") community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of Ucayali. She is 42 years old and a single mother with 1 son. To support herself and her son, she decided to use her first loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$100) to set up a small food stand selling local dishes. She now makes her living from the business selling regional foods (juanes and tacachos, dishes popular in Peru's Amazon region), tending the stand along with her son. They get up very early to make the juanes before Consuelo takes her son to school.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.1,000 (1,000 Peruvian soles or about US$336), to be repaid in 5 months, Consuelo will buy a table, 5 kilograms of rice, 3 chickens, 2 bunches of bananas and a litre of cooking oil.

Consuelo is very happy to have a healthy child who she can send to school and especially satisfied that she can do so even though she is the family's sole breadwinner.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Consuelo pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Almendras, del Jr. Manco Capac 323 del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 años y es madre de 1 hijo, es madre soltera, es así que Consuelo, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300.00 soles decide poner un pequeño puesto para la venta de comida Regional. En la actualidad cuenta con un pequeño puesto donde vende comida regional ( Juanes y tacacho), la misma que atiende junto a su hijo, se levantan muy temprano para preparar los juanes y luego lleva a la escuela a su hijo.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,000 (US$ 336.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 5 meses, comprará una mesa, 5 kilos de arroz, 3 gallinas, 2 racimos de plátano y 1 litro de aceite.

Consuelo está muy contenta de tener a su hijo sano y en la escuela, y satisfecha con ello dado que ella sola puede costear las necesidades de su casa.

loans.use: Buy supplies for restaurant business.

loans.name: Jenny

texts.es:
Jenny belongs to the Luz y Paz ("Light and Peace") community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of Ucayali. She is 33 years old and the mother of 4 children. Her husband works but his income doesn't cover all of the household's expenses so Jenny, with her first loan of S/.300 (300 Peruvian soles or about US$100), decided to set up a small stand selling clothes. She now has a clothing store (for men, women and children) which she tends after taking care of her children.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.1,500 (1,500 Peruvian soles or about US$503), to be repaid in 4 months, she will expand the store and buy a dozen pairs of shorts, 3 dozen sport shirts, 3 dozen blouses and underwear.

Jenny is happy that she can help her husband financially and share the costs of the household; moreover, she feels like a a big success.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Jenny pertenece al Banco Comunal Luz y Paz, del A. H. Santa Petronila Mz C Lt 14 del Distrito de Manantay del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 33 años y es madre de 4 hijos, su esposo es empleado y sus ingresos no alcanza para abastecer las necesidades de la casa, es así que Jenny, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300.00 soles decide poner un pequeño puesto de la venta de ropa. En la actualidad cuenta con una tienda de ropa (para mujeres, niños y caballeros), Jenny después de atender a sus hijos se dedica a su negocio.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos de S/. 1,500 (US$ 503.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, ampliará el local del negocio y comprará 1 docena de bermudas, 3 docenas de polos, 3 docenas de blusas y variedad de ropa interior.

Jenny está muy contenta de apoyar económicamente a su esposo y así aportar con las necesidades de la casa, además se siente una mujer exitosa.

loans.use: Buy bulk supplies of clothing for resale.

loans.name: Amelia De Jesús

texts.es:
Amelia belongs to the Fray Martin ("Brother Martin") community bank in the Peruvian "departamento" of Ucayali. Amelia, 57, is a single mother with 2 children. To support her family, she decided to start a small "plastiqueria" stand (selling plastic goods). She now depends on a kiosk where she sells plastic bags, disposable cups, disposable plates, etc. She gets up very early every day to tend to her business, forging ahead alone, as she's always done. Thanks to this business, she's managed to send both her children to school.

With a recently-granted loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.1,500 (1,500 Peruvian soles or about US$503), to be repaid in 4 months, Amelia will buy a hundred packs of plastic bags; a thousand disposable cups; 500 plastic plates; and 100 kilograms of plastic rope. She will also paint her shop.

Amelia is very happy to have 2 healthy children who were able to finish school. She feels complete.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Amelia pertenece al Banco Comunal Fray Martin, en Jr. Bellavista 755 del Distrito D. Calleria del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 57 años y tiene 2 hijos, es madre soltera, es así que Amelia, con el primer préstamo D. Manuela Ramos D. S/ 300.00 soles deciD. poner un pequeño puesto D. plastiqueria (venta D. artículos D. plástico). En la actualidad cuenta con un kiosko donD. venD. bolsas D. plástico, vasos descartables, platos descartables, etc. Todos los días se levanta muy temprano para atender este negocio, y Amelia sigue adelante sola como siempre lo hizo. Gracias a este negocio educó a todos sus hijos.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 1,500 (US$ 503.00 aprox.), el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará un ciento D. paquetes D. bolsas D. plástico, un millar D. vasos descartables, medio millar D. platos descartables, 100 kilos D. soga D. plástico y pintara su local.

Amelia está muy contenta D. tener a sus 2 hijos sanos y haber logrado que terminen sus estudios. Además se siente una mujer realizada.

loans.use: Buy plastic goods for resale.

loans.name: Sandra

texts.en:
Sandra is an active and positive 21-year-old woman who is determined to succeed in life. She is married and will have her first child very soon, as she’s four months pregnant.

Two years ago, Sandra graduated as a hair stylist from a beauty academy. She wants to exercise her profession and make a living. She needs funds to open a small beauty salon, which she will run within her house.

She will invest her loan in the purchase of materials, such as a blower, hair dying products and hair treatment lotion. She says that she has already bought other products, such as shampoo, face cleansing lotions, and a used hair-washing machine, with her husband's help. The entrepreneur hopes she can get the funds before long so that she can make her dream come true.

loans.use: To buy materials to start a small beauty salon

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es:
Sra. Ana María belongs to the Banco Comunal Luz y Paz (Light and Peace Community Bank) in the Manantay district of Ucayali in Peru. She is 29 years old and is the mother of three children. Her husband is a construction worker, but does not earn much money, so with an initial loan of 300 Peruvian soles from Manuela Ramos, Ana María decided to set up a small stall selling cookies and candies.

She currently has a grocery store, which she runs at the same time as looking after her children. Ana María and her husband get up very early to take care of their young children and then look after the grocery store. It is one of the few grocery stores in this area.

With the recently granted loan from Manuela Ramos, which will be repaid over four months, she will extend her shop and buy four crates of milk, one sack of rice, one sack of sugar, six crates of soda and one pack of cookies.

Ana María is very happy that her children are healthy, and that she has this business to help pay for household needs.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Ana María pertenece al Banco Comunal Luz y Paz, del A. H. Martha Chavez Mz 22 Lt 10 del Distrito de Manantay del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 29 años y es madre de 3 hijos, su esposo es operario de construcción civil, pero tiene un bajo ingreso, por esa razón Ana María, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300.00 soles decide poner un pequeño puesto para la venta de galletas y golosinas.

En la actualidad cuenta con una bodega, la misma que atiende junto a sus hijos, se levantan muy temprano para atender a sus pequeños hijos y luego atender la bodega. En este sector existen pocas bodegas cercanas.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, ampliará el local del negocio y comprará 4 caja de leche, 1 saco de arroz, 1 saco de azúcar, 6 cajas de gaseosa y 1 paquete de galletas.

Ana María está muy contenta de tener a sus hijos sanos y además de tener este negocio para ayudar a atender las necesidades de la casa.

loans.use: To buy various grocery store products.

loans.name: Luz Del Carmen

texts.en:
Luz is an energetic and persistent woman of 29. She has two boys, ages 5 and 4. She and her husband have a general store, which they started three years ago. They sell different kinds of products, such as vegetables, juice, energy drinks, condiments, flour and chocolate.

As products are sold off quickly and demands from customers are very frequent, Luz needs to always have an adequate amount of products available to satisfy the clients’ needs. She is asking for a loan to purchase sacks of beans and rice and large amounts of other goods so that she can reduce her number of trips outside of the township to obtain products. That way, the entrepreneur will increase her income and improve her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy beans, rice and other foodstuffs to supply a general store

loans.name: Merita

texts.es:
Merita belongs to the "Luz y Paz" community bank, located in the district of Manatay, province of Ucayali. She is 42 years old and the mother of 3. Her husband works transporting merchandise to Lima, but his income is not enough to cover household expenses. With Merita´s first loan from Manuela Ramos of 300 soles, she put up a small stand to sell shoes.

Currently, with her husband´s support, she sells mens and childrens shoes to the area's construction workers, motocar drivers and young people.

With her next loan from Manuel Ramos which will be paid back in 4 months, she will expand her business premises and buy 100 pairs of mens shoes, 40 pairs of childrens shoes and 20 pairs of slippers.

Merita is very happy to work with her husband and to be able to educate her childen so they can all get ahead.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Merita pertenece al Banco Comunal Luz y Paz, del Jr. Francia 370 del A. H. Antunez de Mayolo del Distrito de Manantay del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 42 años y es madre de 3 hijos, su esposo se dedica a traer mercadería de Lima, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos del hogar, es así que Merita, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300.00 soles decide poner un puesto de venta de zapatos (calzado).

En la actualidad, se dedica a la venta de calzado para caballeros y niños, los mismos que vende a obreros de construcción civil, motocarristas y jóvenes de la zona. La señora Merita cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos el cual será pagado en 4 meses, ampliará el local del negocio y comprará 100 pares de zapatos para caballeros, 40 pares de zapatos para niños y 20 pares de zapatillas.

Merita está muy contenta de trabajar junto a su esposo y así educar a sus hijos y salir adelante juntos.

loans.use: Purchase of footwear.  Expansion of business premises.

loans.name: Tulia

texts.es:
Tulia belongs to the Banco Comunal Fray Martín of the A. H. Faustino Maldonado Mz E Lt 9, of the Calleria district in the Department (State) of Ucayali. She is 52 years old and is the mother of 5 children. She's separated from her husband and supports her children on her own. For this reason, Tulia, with her first loan provided by Manuela Ramos of 300.00 soles, decided to set up a small stand to sell chickens.

Tulia gets up at 3 in the morning to slaughter and cut up the chickens and sell them. Her children help her with the housework, giving that she finishes selling at 10 in the morning.

With the recent loan received from from Manuela Ramos which will be paid back in 4 months, she will be able to extend her reach to sell to more people, buy 2 cages in which to put the chickens, buy 100 chickens and a plastic container in which to store the giblets.

Tulia is very happy that she can count on this business. Thanks to her business, she can educate her children and pay for the needs of the home.

Translated from Spanish by Kim Baker, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Tulia pertenece al Banco Comunal Fray Martín, del A. H. Faustino Maldonado Mz E Lt 9 del Distrito D. Calleria del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 52 años y es madre D. 5 hijos, está separada D. su esposo y sola tiene que trabajar para sacar adelante a sus hijos. Por esta razón es que Tulia, con el primer préstamo D. Manuela Ramos D. S/ 300.00 soles, deciD. poner un pequeño puesto D. venta D. pollos (aves para consuno). Tulia se levanta a las 3.00 D. la mañana para beneficiar a los pollos y venderlos, sus hijos le ayudan con las tareas D. la casa dado que termina D. vender a las 10.00 D. la mañana. Con el reciente préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos el cual será pagado en 4 meses, ampliará el local del negocio y comprará 2 jabas para poner los pollos, 100 pollos y un embace para conservar la menudencia. Tulia está muy contenta D. contar con este negocio, dado que gracias a ello pueD. educar a sus hijos así como costear las necesidades D. la casa.

loans.use: Purchase of chicken cages and chickens and be able to extend her reach to sell to more customers.

loans.name: Miguelina

texts.es:
Sra. Miguelina belongs to the Banco Comunal Las Almendras (The Almonds Community Bank) in the Calleria district of Ucayali in Peru. She is 62 years old and has one son. Her husband is a traveling salesman, but does not earn enough money to cover household expenses, so with an initial loan of 300 Peruvian soles from Manuela Ramos, Miguelina decided to set up a small stall selling ladies’ purses and shoes.

She still has this small business, which she looks after with her son. As well as taking care of her household chores, she also makes the space in her house to sell women's goods.

With the recently granted loan from Manuela Ramos, which will be repaid over five months, she will make improvements to her shop and buy a dozen purses, 20 pairs of shoes, three dozen earrings and necklaces.

Miguelina is very pleased to be working; she is calm, relaxed and above all, happy, and that’s why she always makes punctual repayments.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Miguelina pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Almendras, del Jr. Manco Capac 270 del Distrito de Calleria del Departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 62 años y es madre de un hijo, su esposo es vendedor ambulante, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para los gastos de la casa, es así que Miguelina, con el primer préstamo de Manuela Ramos de S/ 300.00 soles decide poner un pequeño puesto para vender carteras y zapatos para damas.

En la actualidad cuenta con este pequeño negocio, el mismo que atiende junto a su hijo, además de atender los quehaceres de la casa también se da el espacio para vender mercadería dirigida a mujeres.

Con el reciente préstamo recibido de Manuela Ramos, el cual será pagado en 5 meses, lo utilizará para hacer mejoras en su local y comprar 1 docena de carteras, 20 pares de zapatos, 3 docenas de aretes y collares.

Miguelina está muy contenta de trabajar y se siente tranquila, holgada y sobre todo Feliz, es por ello que se mantiene puntual en sus pagos.

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of ladies' shoes and purses, and maintenance of shop.

loans.name: Augustina Villar

texts.en:
Augustina is an active and hard-working businesswoman. She is 34 years old and has three children, a girl and two boys, ages 14, 12 and 11, respectively, all of whom attend a private school. Her husband works in the town council.

Augustina dedicates herself to the sales of natural medicines. She operates the business in her house, and on the weekends she offers the products door-to-door in the neighborhood. She says that business is very profitable, as she makes a weekly profit of $125.

Augustina hopes she can earn more in order to supply other necessities for her children. She has applied for a loan to buy a larger amount of natural medicines so that she can increase her sales volume. She trusts that if she keeps on working as hard as she is now, before long she will be able to rent a small site where she can sell the medicines.

loans.use: To purchase large amounts of natural medicines to increase sales volume

loans.name: Fuente De Vida Group

texts.es:
The community “Fuente de Vida” or “Fountain of Life” is a consolidated communal bank. The woM. of this group have worked and lived together for almost five years. The group displays great confidence and happiness in working together. It is a dynamic community and it contains a mixture of interesting young and older woM..

Before beginning to work with Friendship Bridge, many of these woM. worked as homemakers or artisans. Like the majority of woM. in Santiago de Atitlan, these woM. work making beaded jewelry and traditional weaving and they are paid exclusively for hand-made work.

However, they have decided to change their future by starting a business venture with Friendship Bridge. Now they want to change their status from that of artisans who are only recompensed for handmade labor to businesswoM. who are recognized for their talent.

For this reason the group is excited to request a loan of approximately $200 US, paid in nine installments, in order to invest in their successful businesses. The majority of the woM. work in knitting and embroidery of traditional dresses. They also work in the purchase and sale of fresh vegetables and the raising of animals. The woM. are going to use their credit to buy bulls (in order to fatten and sell them), to buy fire wood in bulk in order to sell it in the outlying villages, to buy beads in order to make jewelry and to buy raw material for making traditional dresses and embroidery.

The dream of these woM., which they are already realizing, is to see their businesses grow in order to be able to expand their homes and in that way install electricity and water. They would also like to buy land in order to build homes for their children. Finally, the consensus was that the businesses grow in order to send their children to school so that the kids can get ahead. Doña María Elena A. said: “My dream is that my son study in the university and graduate as a lawyer in order to fight injustice in our towns.” Thanks to the loans that they would receive from Kiva, this dream could be achieved.

For health reasons, one of the group members was not able to be present in the photo.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

La ComUnidad “Fuente de Vida” es un banco comunal ya consolidado. Las mujeres de este grupo han trabajado y convivido juntas por casi 5 años. Este grupo de mujeres refleja mucha confianza y alegría al actuar. Es un grupo dinámico y tiene una mezcla interesante de mujeres jóvenes y adultas.

Muchas de estas mujeres antes de empezar con Friendship Bridge trabajaban como ama de llaves dentro de sus casas o eran artesanas. Como la gran mayoría de mujeres en Santiago de Atitlan, estas mujeres trabajan haciendo joyería de mostacilla y tejidos típicos y les pagaban exclusivamente por la mano de obra.

Sin embargo, ellas decidieron cambiar su futuro al emprender una aventura empresarial con Friendship Bridge. Ahora ellas quieren cambiar su estatus de una artesana que solo es recompensada por su mano de obra, a una empresaria a la cual se le reconoce su talento.

Es por esa razón que este grupo se animó a pedir un préstamo de aproximadamente US$200, a nueve cuotas, para invertir en sus negocios exitosos. La mayoría de señoras trabajan en tejido y bordado de trajes típicos. También, trabajan en la compra y venta de verduras y la crianza de animales. Las señoras van a utilizar su crédito para comprar toros (para engordarlos y revenderlos), compra de leña al por mayor y revenderla en las aldeas alejadas, comprar mostacilla para producir joyas y para comprar materia prima para elaborar trajes típicos y bordados.

Los sueños de estas señoras, que ya lo están viviendo, es que su negocio mejore para poder ampliar su casita y de esa manera instalar luz y agua. También les gustaría comprar un terreno para poder construir una casa para sus hijos. Finalmente, el consenso fue que el negocio mejore para poder mandar sus hijos a la escuela para que puedan salir adelante. Doña Maria Elena A. dijo: “mi sueño es que mi hijo llegue a estudiar en la universidad y se gradúe como abogado para luchar contra las injusticias en nuestros pueblos.” Gracias al préstamo que vamos a recibir de Kiva ese sueño se va a poder lograr.

Por problemas de salud una de las compañeras no se pudo presentar en la foto.

loans.use: In order to buy and sell traditional clothing and fabrics.  For the purchase of raw material for the making of traditional dresses. To purchase raw material for making beaded jewelry.

loans.name: Estrellas Del Cielo Group

texts.es:
The communal Bank Estrellas del Cielo (Stars of Heaven) is a consolidated women’s group. It is characteristically distinctive, as can be noticed in the group organization and the grace with which they treat foreigners. It is important to note that the majority of the women are asking for the same amount of money, thus reflecting their common development in the business world.

Although only two women in this group can write and all have overwhelming responsibilities in their homes, you notice ambition and hope in their eyes.

Before asking for their first loan with Friendship Bridge, most of these women worked in their homes as housewives, while others wove beautiful huipiles (native Mayan textiles and blouses) without significant financial gain. However, with this loan from us, they’ve decided to change their lives.

Most of the women have decided to continue weaving the native textiles but more successfully. With these loans they’ll be able to expand their businesses. Manuela A. Ixtos commented that with the next loan that she’s going to get, she’ll be able to buy high quality materials at wholesale and reduce her operating costs. The loan will also be used to raise farm animals, production of textiles, and to purchase fertilizer and seeds.

The dreams of the women who participate in Estrellas del Cielo are concentrated on the futures of their children. The majority of the women wish to expand their business in order to gain a little more money and be able to send their children to school.
