This way they’ll be able to spare their children the difficult experiences they had growing up on the hard streets of Nahualá.

Translated from Spanish by Lizella West, Kiva Volunteer.

El banco comunal Estrellas del Cielo es un grupo de señoras ya consolidado. Esta característica distintiva, se puede notar en la organización del grupo, y en la soltura con la cual tratan a los extranjeros. Es importante notar que la gran mayoría de señoras están solicitando la misma cantidad de dinero. Esto refleja que todas las señoras se están desarrollando empresarialmente al mismo paso.

A pesar de que en este grupo únicamente dos señoras pueden firmar y todas tienen abrumante responsabilidades en sus hogares, se les nota una mirada fuerte y llena de esperanza.

Antes de pedir su primer préstamo con Friendship Bridge, muchas de estas señoras trabajaban en sus hogares como empleadas domésticas, mientras que otras tejían huipiles preciosos sin lograr ninguna ganancia significativa. Sin embargo, con el préstamo que ellas solicitaron a dicha institución, ellas decidieron cambiar sus vidas.

Muchas de las clientas han decidido seguir el camino de tejidos típicos pero, de una manera más exitosa. Ahora con los préstamos ellas han decidido ampliar sus negocios. Manuela A. Ixtos comentó que con el próximo préstamo que ella va a recibir, va a ser capaz de comprar materia prima al por mayor, reduciendo sus costos operativos. El préstamo también va a ser utilizado para la crianza de animales, la producción de telas y para la compra de abono y semillas.

Los sueños de las señoras que participan en Estrellas del Ciclo se centran en el futuro de sus hijos. La gran mayoría de señoras quieren ampliar su negocio para que de esa manera ellas puedan ganar un poco más de dinero y así mandar sus hijos a la escuela. De esa manera ellas van a evitar que sus hijos e hijas vivan las difíciles experiencias que ellas vivieron en las duras calles de Nahualá.

loans.use: To buy high quality materials in order to elaborate native woven textiles.  Reselling of woven textiles.  Raising farm animals and crops.

loans.name: Srey

texts.en:
Mrs. E. Srey was married in 1984 and has three children, two sons and one daughter. She learned to weave silk from her neighbor in 1992 and began her silk weaving business in the same year. She is also buying and reselling fish in the village in the morning, and continues weaving silk in the afternoon. Her husband, Mr. Kheng Khoeun, is a construction contractor. He used to work for a neighbor and started a contracting construction business by himself in 1990. Two of her sons are also working; one is a security guard and other one is working as construction worker with her husband.

After borrowing money from MAXIMA several times, her living condition is getting better. She has a chance to set up a new loom for her daughter.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA four times already. Now she is asking for a loan in the amount of $1,000. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials and fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom and buying and reselling fish.

loans.use: Purchasing silk materials and fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom and buying and reselling fish.

loans.name: Nur

texts.id:
Nur V. moves to Bali with her parents. After getting married she still lives in the area with her husband. Initial capital was obtained from her husband. She started this business a year ago. Every day she bought 30 kg of 'chicken feet' raw materials at a price of Rp4500.00 (about 45 US cents)/kg. She bought those 'chicken feet' from the chicken slaughterer in Badung. These made ceker chips are placed in school cantines and other food stalls nearby. Each package of chips is sold for Rp1000 (about US10 cents). Daily profit are about Rp20,000-30,000 (about US$2-3). Her husband works as used shoes sales with an income of Rp250,000 (about US$25)/month, was very much helped by this business. Daily expenses of Rp15,000 (about US$1.50) with 2 children need income that should be enough.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Nur V. sejak kecil tinggal di Bali bersama orang tuanya. Setelah menikah ia tetap tinggal di daerah itu bersama suaminya. Dia memulai usaha ini dengan modal awal dari suaminya. Usaha ini dimulai sejak setahun yang lalu. Setiap hari ia membeli bahan krupuk (‘ceker’) sejumlah 30 kg dimana harga per kilonya Rp 4.500,00. Dia membeli ‘ceker’ – ‘ceker’ tersebut dari tukang potong ayam di Badung. Krupuk ‘ceker’ hasil olahannya dititipkan di kantin sekolah dan di warung –warung sekitar tempat tinggalnya. Satu bungkus krupuk ia jual seharga Rp 1.000,00. Keuntungan yang dia peroleh antara Rp 20.000,00 – Rp 30.000,00/hari. Suaminya yang bekerja sebagai penjual sepatu bekas dengan penghasilan Rp 250.000,00/bulan sangat terbantu dengan usahanya ini. Biaya hidup per hari Rp 15.000,00 dengan anak dua orang tentu memerlukan penghasilan yang memadai.

loans.use:
To buy raw materials of: 'Chicken feet'

Membeli bahan mentah berupa 'ceker' ayam

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Ny was married in 1993 and has five children, two sons and three daughters. She has been in the business of selling bananas since 1993. In 2004, she started an additional business planting food crops. Her husband is also in business with her, planting food crops and running a motor taxi. Three of her children are studying at primary school in the village and the other two are at home.

She is asking for a loan from MAXIMA for the second time in the amount of $500. She will use this loan to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to run his motor taxi business.

loans.use: Purchasing a motorbike for running a motor taxi.

loans.name: Rachna

texts.en:
Mrs. T. Rachna was married in 1998 and has 2 daughters. She has been in the business of growing and selling flowers since 1993. She and her husband are living under the custody of her widowed mother who also plants flowers and food crops. Her husband is also in business of doing farming with her.   
>p>
She is asking for a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $400. Some of the loan will be used to buy a motorbike for carrying the products to sell in the market in Phnom Penh, and some for purchasing flowers and reselling them.

loans.use: Buy motorbike purchase flowers to resell in the market.

loans.name: Simona Esperanza

texts.es:
Simona sells bread, which she purchases in bulk from bakeries and then sells at retail, and today she sells other items as well. She's been in the business for 22 years and recalls that she started with a small loan from a relative. Previously she sold fresh bread out of a basket on the street.

Simona works outdoors. Currently she has integrated new products to her business such as jewelry and footwear to add variety and attracts new customers. She has been receiving loans for the last three years and has improved her business thanks to them. The business has also improved her quality of life and helped give her son a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

Doña Simona vende pan, compra en gran cantidad en las Panaderias y vender al detalle, y hoy en día tiene venta de otros productos. Lleva 22 años con este negocio y recuerda que incio con doscientos córdobas con un prestamo de un familiar. Antes vendía el pan en un canasto y salia por las calles a ofrecer a sus cientes el pancito fresco.

Su puesto de trabajo está al aire libre. Actualmente ha ingresado nuevos productos a su negocio como Oro Laminado y Calzado para variar en su negocio y atraer otra clientela. Lleva 3 años trabajando con CREDITOS y ha aprovechado de buena manera los 66 créditos, ha obtenido buenos beneficios, le ha ayudado a mejorar su negocio, su familia a mejorado su nivel de vida y a darle una buena educacion a su hijo.

loans.use: Purchase bread from wholesale suppliers and sell to customers.

loans.name: Narin

texts.en:
Mrs. P. Narin was married in 1981 and has five children, two sons and three daughters. She has been in the business of selling Khmer noodles and rice soup since 1992. All of her children are living under her custody. However, one daughter is working at the garment factory in Ta Khmao district, one is working in Phnom Penh and the other three are studying at the local school. Her husband stays at home. He can not work because he is blind in both eyes.

She is asking for a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $600. She will use the borrowed money to expand her Khmer noodle business and to repair her house.

loans.use: Expanding Khmer noodle business and repairing house.

loans.name: Saeful

texts.id:
Saeful B. lives in Abianbase street. He rents a room for Rp230,000 (about US$25)/month. That does not include electric and water expenses. In this business he is helped by his wife. Saeful buys raw materilas in the form of raw chicken. He bought it at Abianbase market. Saeful sells his fried chicken by push cart. He sells it in a place about 50 meters from his room. He is selling from 3:00PM to 10:00PM at night. Profit is about Rp1,700,000 (about US$175)/month. He is running this business for his family. He has a wife an a toddler. Daily expense is about Rp15,000 (about US$1.60).

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Gwan Liong Ang, Kiva volunteer.

Saeful B. tinggal di Jl. Raya Abianbase. Dia menyewa sebuah kamar. Satu kamar seharga Rp 230.000,00/bulan. Itu sudah termasuk biaya listrik dan air. Dalam menjalankan usahanya, dia dibantu oleh isterinya. Saeful membeli bahan baku berupa ayam mentah. Dia membelinya di Pasar Abianbase. Saeful melakukan usaha jual ayam gorengnya dengan sarana rombong. Dia menjualnya di dekat tempat kosnya, kira – kira 50 meter jauhnya. Dia berjualan mulai pukul 3 sore sampai dengan pukul 10 malam. Keuntungan usahanya Rp 1.700.000,00/bulan. Dia menekuni usaha ini demi keluarganya. Dia memiliki satu orang isteri dan satu orang anak yang belum sekolah. Biaya hidup per hari mereka sebesar Rp 15.000,00.

loans.use:
To buy raw chicken as raw materials

Membeli bahan baku berupa ayam mentah

loans.name: Het

texts.en:
Mr. K. Het was married in 1988 and has five children, three sons and two daughters. He has been in the business of buying and reselling cows since 2002. He buys cows from his commune and other communes for reselling in other provinces far from his home. His wife is in the business of selling grocery items at home. She buys grocery items from the market in Phnom Penh. He has not finished primary school and his wife has never attended school.

He has borrowed money from MAXIMA three times already. Now he is asking a loan in the amount of $1,000. He will use this loan to purchase three more cows for feeding and reselling in other provinces. After borrowing money from Maxima previously, his living has gotten better because he has more funds for expanding his business.

loans.use: Buying and reselling cows.

loans.name: Lan

texts.en:
Mrs. H. Lan was married in 1999 and has two daughters. She has been in the business of running a grocery store since 2004. She is also raising pigs at home. Her husband is growing rice and fishing. She has never attended school and her husband has not finished high school. One of her daughters is studying in primary school and other one is still young and stays at home.

She is asking for a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $100. She will use this money to buy more grocery items for her stock in order to expand her business.

loans.use: Buying more grocery items for her stock.

loans.name: Srey Yol

texts.en:
Mrs. T. Srey Yol and Mr. Chhoeun Chhat were married in 2006 and have one daughter. Srey Yol just started her grocery store in early 2007. Her husband fishes in the Mekong River close to the village. Both of them are living with their parents.

She is asking a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $300. She will use this money to buy more grocery items for her stock in order to expand her business. She expects that after receiving money from Maxima, the progress of her business will get better and better.

loans.use: Buying more grocery items for her stock.

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Mrs. U. Lay was married in 1983 and has five children, three sons and two daughters. She learned to weave silk from her mother in 1980. She began her silk weaving business in the same year. She has finished primary school. Her husband, Mr. Uth Thorn, is working at the AKIMEX Company as chief of the warehouse. He has finished high school.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times already. Now she is asking a loan in the amount of $500. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials and fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use: Purchasing silk materials and fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Hor

texts.en:
Mr. L. Hor was married in 1994 and has one daughter. Since 2006, he has been in the business of running a motorbike repairing service in front of his house. He learned to repair motorbikes in 1987. His spouse is assisting him at home. His daughter is studying.

She is asking for a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of $500. He will use this money to buy more motorbike and bicycle spare parts for his stock so that he can save money and time by going very often to the city to buy them.

loans.use: Purchasing motorbike and bicycle spare parts for his stock.

loans.name: Sokhun

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Sokhun was married in 2000 and has three children, two sons and one daughter. She learned to weave silk from her mother in1987. She began her silk weaving business in the same year. She also continued training her husband to weave. He is currently weaving silk at home as well. Only their eldest son is studying at the local primary school. The other two are still young and stay at home.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA three times already. Now she is asking a loan in the amount of $400. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread and fees for selecting and preparing silk on her loom and her husband's.

loans.use: Purchasing silk materials, sewing thread and fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms.

loans.name: Khoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Khoeun was married in 1978 and has three children, one son and two daughters. She has been in the business of selling fish since 1983. Her husband is a fisherman. He gives the fish he catches to his wife to sell in the market.

She has borrowed money from MAXIMA five times already. Now she is asking for a loan in the amount of $500. She will use this loan to purchase a wooden boat, boat motor and fishing net for her husband to expand the fishing activity.

loans.use: Purchasing a wooden boat, boat motor and fishing net .

loans.name: Pisey

texts.en:
Mr. Pisey S., 42, is married with four children, ages 3-14. He and his family live in a modest home south of Phnom Penh along National Road 2. For the past 17 years, Pisey has been a construction worker. His work entails traveling to various building sites, usually residential homes, within his commune (a collection of 3 villages). His wife, Vanno, stays at home taking care of their children and farming rice. Vanno has been a farmer for almost 20 years and grows the rice both for the family's personal use and to resell.

Pisey is requesting a second loan from MAXIMA in the amount of US$ 400. He will use this loan to purchase a refurbished motorbike-scooter to allow him to more easily get to and from work. Currently, Pisey rides with a co-worker, but having a motorbike of his own will allow him more flexibility with his work schedule. There are no other realistic options for transport in this rural area.

Of their four children, two currently attend local schools and one attends a private school where he is learning English. In the future, Pisey hopes to continue saving money to ensure their children are able to pursue higher education.

loans.use: Purchasing a motorbike-scooter for transport to construction sites

loans.name: Kalsoom

texts.en: My name is Kalsoom B.. I am married and I live with my family in Arifwala, a small city in Pakistan. I am a mother of seven children, all of whom attend school. My husband sells steel utensils and I own a few cows and I sell their milk. Last year, I took a loan and added a cow to the existing ones. The profits out of this business helped me enroll my children in school and pay off debts to one of the money lenders. Now, I want to buy another cow for my business. This way my income will increase significantly and I will make savings for my children’s future.

loans.use: Buy a cow

loans.name: Asiah

texts.en:
I am Asiah P. from Arifwala, a small size city in Pakistan. I am 25 and married. I embroider clothes on order and my husband is an electrician. He owns a shop in a nearby market where he sells various electric items. His shop does well and generates good profits. Now, he wants to expand his business further for which he requires a loan. He will buy items such as batteries, wires, and energy-saving bulbs in a suitable quantity. 
We want to have a well-established business before our child comes into this world so that we can ensure him a secure future.

loans.use: Buy electrical goods for the store

loans.name: Shumaila

texts.en:
I am requesting a loan of US $350 for my embroidery business. I embroider ladies shirts and trousers with a computerized embroidery machine. I get a good number of orders, but I wish to expand my business further. If you lend to me, I will buy another computerized embroidery machine.

I am married and a mother of one. I live with my family in Arifwala, a small city in Pakistan. My husband is a painter and he paints buildings on contract. My husband's work is not a steady source of income, therefore, I wish to establish mine.

loans.use: Buy a computerized embroidery machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Incraese inventory

loans.name: Asma

texts.en: My name is Asma I.. I am 22 and married. I live with my husband in Arifwala, a small city in Pakistan. My husband is a rickshaw driver and I embroider clothes on order  from various shopkeepers. At present, I make handmade embroidered dresses but now I want to buy a computerized embroidery machine for myself. This way I will be able to produce clothes with the latest designs and fashions in a large quantity. It will also save my time on every item that I create. Please give me a loan.

loans.use: Buy an embroidery machine

loans.name: Haji Khan

texts.en: Haji Khan lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with 4 children. He is the owner of a business that sells wood. He has been involved in this business for more than 10 years, and he has a good number of customers and clients. He wants to expand his business, so he requested an individual loan to complete his stock and make a good income. He wants to help his family and enroll his children in a better education center. He is happy with his family.

loans.use: To complete his stock

loans.name: Ghous

texts.en: I am Ghous B. from a small city, Arifwala, Pakistan. I am 45, married and a mother of five children. My husband operates a knitwear shop in a busy neighboring market. He buys knitwear for his shop from various knitting factories. Earlier, he took loans and invested in his shop which yielded higher profits to us. Winter is around the corner and therefore, the demand for knitwear will rise sharply. For that reason, my husband wants to buy a stock of knitwear including socks, sweaters and vests. He requires a loan of US$300 for this purpose. Our business yields relatively much higher profits in winter, so this is the time for us to make decent profits for ourself. I plan to save some portion of these profits for future usage.

loans.use: Buy a stock of knitwear

loans.name: Mohammad Zahar

texts.en: Mohammad Zahar lives in district 6 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and has 3 children. He is a carpenter. He has a small shop. He is a hard-working man. He wants to enlarge his shop, so he wants to take an individual loan to buy new machines for his shop and stock his necessary materials. He wants to attract more clients and make a good income to support his family. He is happy.

loans.use: To buy new machines and stock his necessary materials.

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en: I am a mother of ten, six boys and four girls. I live with my family in a small town, Arifwala, Pakistan. I am a textile designer and I embroider clothes to order. My husband drives a rickshaw (local three-wheeled taxi). He bought his rickshaw by acquiring a loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution based in Pakistan. He repaid the loan installments on time leaving him with decent profits. Now my son has also learned to drive and I want to buy him a rickshaw as well. This way he will help us to manage our household expenses. I request a loan of US$350 for this purpose.

loans.use: Buy a rickshaw

loans.name: Fridah

texts.en: Fridah O. is a 70-year-old widow who lives in Sagam Siaya Kenya. She has four living children (initially had 5 but 1 died).  Fridah has struggled  and spent all her finances raising her children after the death of her husband. She is a hard-working mother  who spends much of her time taking care of her only hope: a dairy cattle she acquired in 2002. This has really made a difference in my  life!!! she says. Besides producing milk, it has also given birth to six calfs.  It  produces not less than 30 liters of milk a day, which she sells to the community. Fridah hopes to  purchase high-yield dairy cattle that will produce more than 40 litres of milk a day with the US $700 she has applied for.

loans.use: Purchase high-yield dairy cattle breed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a kerosene pump

loans.name: Chin

texts.en: Mr. Chin V., 28, is married to a woman, aged 28, and lives in Batambong province, Cambodia. He works buying and selling recyclable items, earning around $3.70/day. His wife works as a housewife looking after her two school-aged kids. Mr Chin V. hopes to use this loan to purchase a motorcycle to use for his business’s transportation because he expects the motorcycle will make his business grow faster, easier, and more effectively.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for his business transportation.
